entry.title: [BIP Proposal] Soft Fork Compromise on op_return to Resolve Current Bitcoin Controversies
entry.summary:
The email discusses the reasoning behind not decreasing the size limit for a certain Bitcoin protocol parameter, pointing out that major miners had already disregarded this rule, making any lesser adjustment ineffective in aligning with the actual mining practices. This mismatch between protocol specification and mining reality led to a problematic situation, suggesting that an earlier increment of the limit might have avoided the issue if not for the adverse effects of targeted harassment experienced by a community member, which hindered open discussion and progressive adjustments.
The sender reflects on the missed opportunity for a gradual increase of the limit, which could have been more manageable and perhaps less controversial than outright removal. However, the economic forces and incentives within the Bitcoin ecosystem naturally lean towards removal of such limits when users are willing to pay for it. This trend was anticipated as early as 2014, particularly after changes were made to allow certain types of transactions again. The message indicates that policy attempts to guide behavior within the Bitcoin network can only serve as a weak encouragement, prone to obsolescence as market dynamics and miner actions evolve.
Furthermore, the email addresses the implications of policy bypassing, emphasizing how aligning rules with miner behavior could inadvertently lead to cycles of transaction failures and possibly encourage mechanisms that favor mining centralizationâ€”contrary to the decentralized ethos of Bitcoin. It also touches upon the broader conversation about the utility and impact of certain transactions, using the example of a fake pubkey user as a case where avoiding additional strain on the blockchain's storage (utxo bloat) is considered a tangible benefit, rather than speculative concern. This perspective underscores the complexity of managing digital currency protocols in a way that balances technical constraints, economic incentives, and the diverse priorities of its user base.
